results.title: France panorama. [No. 67/01]
results.brief_description: French cinemagazine items: 1. The New Year, 1st January 1967 - the Diplomatic corp wish the President a Happy New Year. 2. Fashion - the surreal fashion world of 1967, including the infamous “canned dress”. Includes Paco Rabanne’s Parisian workshop. 3. Toulouse future capital of science and research - shows Toulouse and the largest scientific settlement in Europe.

results.title: France panorama. [No. 66/50]
results.brief_description: French cinemagazine items: Christmas in Paris - Highlights the various French customs involved with celebrating Christmas including the consuming of shellfish, decorating the city streets and shop fronts, and attending Church. Also includes images of the homeless in Paris being given special packages for this festive date.

results.title: France panorama. [No. 65?/38]
results.brief_description: French cinemagazine items including: 1. Le Paquebot des sables - Shows a dredge in South France preparing for the beaching of the liner ‘Lydia’. 2. Le Monde de Miro - shows paintings on cardboard by artist Joan Miro. 3. Sports nautiques - coverage of French water-skiers. 4. Vu pour voux - a look at Americans in Gourin in Britanny, north-west France. 5. Two views of Paris in August - 6.00am and 9.00am and special luxury cattery in Parisian suburb.

results.title: France and its people
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Milan Herzog
results.brief_description: Depicts the life of a Parisian family, including a visit to the family farm in Normandy. Provides an introduction to the geography, industry, agriculture, customs, religion, art, social and economic problems, democratic traditions and overseas relationships of France. Emphasises the close ties of friendship between France and the United States, and describes French contributions to Western civilisation.

results.title: Fran
results.creator_credit: Barron Films, Paul D. Barron, David Rapsey and Glenda Hambly
results.brief_description: Fran never knew her father, her mother was an alcoholic and she was a ward of the state at age five. Now in her thirties, Fran lives with her three children in suburbia. She is restless and has no intention of settling down. Fran has a way of attracting men and pick ups Jeff, a barman. Their relationship develops to a point where Fran is willing to follow him around the country. Unfortunately, Fran’s three children do not fit in with Jeff’s plans and Fran, blinded by love, dumps them with relatives for a “few days”. A “few days” becomes a few months and the children are placed in a welfare home. Fran’s life then becomes an endless battle with debt collectors and welfare officials, not only fighting for her children but fighting to be loved herself. Cast: Noni Hazlehurst, Alan Fletcher.

results.title: Framing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Looks at the notion of the television camera putting a frame around the world. Discusses on-screen and off-screen space, real and apparent size, and the frame within the frame. Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson.
